questions.question:
Question 1: A synapse is a junction between  
.
questions.explanation:
Impulses are transmitted from one nerve cell to another cell at junctions called synapse. These are 
the junctions where the axon or some other portion of one cell (the presynaptic cell) terminates on 
the dendrites, soma, or axon of another neuron or, in some cases, a muscle or gland cell (the 
postsynaptic cell). There are two major types of synapses: • Chemical • Electrical When a neuron terminates on a muscle , it is called a neuromuscular junction . This is an example 
of a chemical synapse . 181 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 2: All of the following are true regarding chemical synapses except

options.a: These are the most common type of synapses
options.b: Neurotransmitter is produced by the presynaptic neuron
options.c: Protoplasmic continuity between pre- and post- synaptic membrane ensures faster conduction

questions.explanation:
Chemical synapses are interneuronal junctions without protoplasmic continuity. Most of the synapses used for signal transmission in the central nervous system of the human 
being are chemical synapses. In these synapses, the first neuron (presynaptic neuron) secretes neurotransmitters at its nerve 
ending synapse. This transmitter, in turn, acts on receptor proteins in the membrane of the next 
neuron (post-synaptic neuron) to excite the neuron, inhibit it, or modify its sensitivity in some 
other way. As neurotransmitters are released only by the pre-synaptic neuron, the synaptic conduction in the 
CNS is only orthodromic (unidirectional). 182 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 3: In a typical chemical synaptic cleft, the extracellular distance between the presynaptic plasma 
membrane and the postsynaptic plasma membrane is approximately
questions.explanation:
In a typical chemical synaptic cleft, the extracellular distance between the presynaptic plasma 
membrane and the postsynaptic plasma membrane is approximately 20-40nm.

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following is true regarding neurotransmitters?

options.a: All neurotransmitter are derived from amino acids
options.b: Nitric oxide is a neurotransmitter in the CNS
options.c: They do not act on ionotropic receptors
options.d: They are released on repolarization of the nerve

questions.explanation:
Nitric oxide is a neurotransmitter in the CNS. Neurotransmitters are the substances that mediate chemical signaling between neurons. They can 
be choline esters, biogenic amines, amino acids, and neuropeptides. Two main classes of chemical substances that serve as neurotransmitters: 183 
Sold by @itachibot • small-molecule neurotransmitter (acetylcholine) • large molecule neurotransmitter (enkephalin) They can act on ionotropic receptors (ligand-gated ion channels) and/or metabotropic receptors on 
the postsynaptic membrane to produce a change in membrane potential to bring about their 
action. Criteria for the substance to be neurotransmitter: • the substance must be demonstrated to be present in the presynaptic terminal. • the cell must be able to synthesize the substance. • should be released on depolarization of the terminal. • there should be specific receptors for it on the postsynaptic membrane. • if the substance is applied exogenously to the postsynaptic membrane at physiologic 
concentration, the response of the postsynaptic cell must mimic the in vivo response.

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following is not a monoamine neurotransmitter?
questions.explanation:
GABA is not a monoamine neurotransmitter. It is an amino acid. Biogenic amines are small, charged molecules that are synthesized from amino acids and contain 
an amino group (R—NH2). Amines known to act as neurotransmitters are dopamine, 
norepinephrine (noradrenaline), epinephrine (adrenaline), serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine 
[5-HT]). Amino acids and their derived amines acting as neurotransmitters: • Tyrosine - catecholamines : dopamine, norepinephrine, and epinephrine . • Tryptophan - serotonin • Histidine - histamine

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following is true regarding metabotropic neurotransmitters?

options.a: They act through second messenger systems
options.b: They bind to cationic channels and increase influx of Na
options.c: They bind to anionic channels and increase influx of Cl
options.d: They inhibit the fusion of synaptic vesicle with the synaptic cleft

questions.explanation:
Neurotransmitter receptors that act through second messenger systems are called metabotropic 
receptors. Neurotransmitters bind to receptors on the post-synaptic membrane to activate ion channels in 
one of the two ways: • by gating ion channels directly (ionotropic receptors). • by activating a second messenger (metabotropic receptor) for a prolonged postsynaptic neuronal 
excitation or inhibition. Most commonly activated is a G-protein coupled membrane receptor. The following four changes can occur usually after binding to a G-protein coupled receptor: • Opening specific ion channels through the post-synaptic cell membrane. 184 
Sold by @itachibot • Activation of cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) or cyclic guanosine monophosphate 
(cGMP) in the neuronal cell. • Activation of one or more intracellular enzymes. • Activation of gene transcription. Activation of gene transcription is one of the most important 
effects of activation of the second messenger systems because gene transcription can cause 
formation of new proteins within the neuron, thereby changing its metabolic machinery or its 
structure.

questions.question: Question 10: Which is not true about neuromodulators?

options.a: Modify the postsynaptic neuron’s response to a specific neurotransmitter
options.b: May change the presynaptic neuron’s release of a transmitter
options.c: May be released by the presynaptic neuron along with the neurotransmitter

questions.explanation:
Neuromodulators typically have actions that are slower than neurotransmitters. Neuromodulators are chemicals released by neurons that have little or no direct effects on their 
own but can modify the effects of neurotransmitters. They can modify the postsynaptic neuron’s response to a neurotransmitter and they can change 
how much of a neurotransmitter the presynaptic neuron synthesizes or releases. Neuromodulators also can be released by the presynaptic neuron along with the neurotransmitter.

questions.question:
Question 11: A medical student was doing research in a laboratory that studies the neuromuscular 
junction. Which of the following events at the junction are listed in correct sequential order?

options.a: Motor neuron action potential, acetylcholine release, Ca2+ entry at the endplate
options.b: Ca2+ entry into the motor nerve terminal, acetylcholine release, Na+ entry at the endplate
options.c: Ca2+ entry into the motor nerve terminal, Na+ entry at the endplate, motor neuron action
options.d: Na+ entry at the endplate, acetylcholine release, muscle fiber action potential

questions.explanation:
Events Occurring at the Chemical Synapse: The action potential arriving at the end of the motor neuron increases the permeability of its 
endings to Ca2+  Ca2+ enters the endings and triggers a marked increase in exocytosis of the 
acetylcholine-containing synaptic vesicles  Binding of acetylcholine to nicotinic receptors increases the Na+ and K+ conductance  Resultant influx of Na+ produces a local depolarizing potential, the endplate potential  The current created by this local potential depolarizes the adjacent muscle membrane to its firing 
level  Action potentials are generated on either side of the endplate and are conducted away from the 
endplate in both directions along the muscle fiber. This muscle action potential, in turn, initiates 
muscle contraction. Acetylcholine is then removed from the synaptic cleft by acetylcholinesterase, which is present in 
high concentration at the neuromuscular junction. 187 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 12: Excitatory postsynaptic potential (EPSP) is due to the influx of  
.
questions.explanation:
Excitatory postsynaptic potential (EPSP) is due to the influx of sodium ions (Na+). At the post-synaptic membrane, neurotransmitters binding to receptors generate responses that 
can be excitatory or inhibitory. If it generates an excitatory response (makes the membrane more 
electrically positive/ depolarized), it is an excitatory postsynaptic potential (EPSP) because it 
makes the cell more likely to reach an action potential. EPSP may be due to • The opening of sodium channels or calcium channels to allow large numbers of positive 
electrical charges to flow to the interior of the postsynaptic cell. • Depressed conduction through chloride or potassium channels or both. • Various changes in the internal metabolism of the postsynaptic neuron to increase the number of 
excitatory membrane receptors or decrease the number of inhibitory membrane receptors. 188 
Sold by @itachibot As seen in the figure, following the discharge of the sensory neuron, there is positivity in the 
motor neuron signifying a EPSP.

questions.question: Question 13: Inhibitory Postsynaptic Potential (IPSP) is due to influx of
questions.explanation:
Inhibitory Postsynaptic Potential (IPSP) is due to the influx of chloride ions (Cl-). If, binding of a neurotransmitter causes the postsynaptic membrane to become more negative 
(hyperpolarized), it is called an inhibitory postsynaptic potential (IPSP) because hyperpolarization 
moves the membrane potential farther from the threshold and makes the cell less likely to reach 
an action potential. IPSP may be due to : • Increase in Cl- influx. This action causes diffusion of negatively charged chloride ions from 
outside the postsynaptic neuron to the inside, thereby carrying negative charges inward and 
increasing the negativity inside. This leads to hyperpolarization. • Increase in K+ efflux. This action causes positive ions to diffuse to the exterior, which causes 
increased negativity inside the neuron, which leads to hyperpolarization. • Activation of receptor enzymes that increase the number of inhibitory synaptic receptors or 
decrease the number of excitatory receptors.

questions.question: Question 14: The following effect in the motor neuron is due to:

options.a: Opening of chloride ion channels through the pre-synaptic neuronal membrane
options.b: Increase in conductance of potassium ions to the inside of the neuron
options.c: Activation of receptor enzymes that increase the number of inhibitory synaptic receptors
options.d: Increase in conductance of sodium ions inside the neuron

questions.explanation:
Activation of receptor enzymes that increase the number of inhibitory synaptic receptors can 
cause the effect shown, namely, the generation of IPSP. In the figure given, there is an increased negativity in the motor neuron following the action 
potential in the interneuron. So, the synaptic potential is IPSP. This can be caused at the 189 
Sold by @itachibot postsynaptic membrane due to Cl- influx, K+ efflux or activation of receptor enzymes that increase 
the number of inhibitory synaptic receptors or decrease the number of excitatory receptors. Other options: • Opening of chloride ion channels through the post-synaptic neuronal membrane. • Increase in conductance of potassium ions to the outside of the postsynaptic neuron. • Increase in conductance of sodium ions inside the neuron causes the generation of an EPSP.

questions.question: Question 15: Slow inhibitory postsynaptic potential (IPSP) is generated by all except
questions.explanation:
Slow EPSPs and IPSPs are not generated by skeletal muscles. Slow excitatory postsynaptic potentials (EPSPs) and inhibitory postsynaptic potential (IPSPs) are 
seen in autonomic ganglia, cardiac, and smooth muscle, and cortical neurons. EPSPs and IPSPs occur after a latency of 0.5ms while slow EPSPs and IPSPs occur after a latency 
of 100–500 ms and last for several seconds. The slow EPSPs are due to a decrease in K+ efflux, 
and the slow IPSPs are due to an increase in K+ efflux.

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following physiologic processes is not correctly matched?

options.c: Presynaptic inhibition: GABA-B receptors decrease K+ conductance.
options.d: Presynaptic inhibition: GABA-A receptors increase Cl– conductance.

questions.explanation:
GABA-B receptors are present in the spinal cord and appear to mediate presynaptic inhibition via 
a G-protein that produces an increase in K+ conductance. PRE-SYNAPTIC INHIBITION • Presynaptic inhibition is a process mediated by neurons whose terminals are on excitatory 
endings, forming axoaxonal synapses. • The first transmitter shown to produce presynaptic inhibition was GABA. On the pre-synaptic 
membrane • Acting via GABA-A receptors, GABA increases Cl– conductance. • GABA-B receptors appear to mediate presynaptic inhibition via a G-protein that produces an 
increase in K+ conductance. • This leads to hyperpolarization of the pre-synaptic membrane and inhibition of release of the 
neurotransmittor from the pre-synaptic neuron. 190 
Sold by @itachibot POST-SYNAPTIC INHIBITION • Postsynaptic inhibition occurs when an inhibitory transmitter such as glycine or GABA is 
released from a presynaptic nerve terminal onto the postsynaptic neuron to induce an IPSP in the 
postsynaptic neuron. • In the figure shown below, an inhibitory transmitter such as GABA is released from the nerve 
terminals of an inhibitory interneuron (dark) that synapses on a postsynaptic neuron.

questions.question: Question 17: Renshaw cell inhibition is
questions.explanation:
Renshaw cell inhibition is an example of feedback inhibition. The axon of a spinal motor neuron has a recurrent collateral that synapses on an inhibitory 
interneuron that terminates on the cell body of the same and other motor neurons. The inhibitory 
interneuron is called a Renshaw cell and its neurotransmitter is glycine. 191 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 18: Feedforward inhibition is seen in
questions.explanation:
Feedforward inhibition is seen in the cerebellum. In the cerebellum, stimulation of basket cells / 
stellate cells produces IPSPs in the Purkinje cells (i.e, inhibits Purkinje cells) In feedforward inhibition, a presynaptic cell excites an inhibitory interneuron which then inhibits 
the next follower cell. In cerebellum (Refer flow chart): This arrangement is called feed-forward inhibition which presumably limits the duration of 
excitation produced by any given afferent volley. Note: Renshaw cell carries out the negative feedback inhibition of a spinal motor neuron. 192 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 19: Presynaptic facilitation is due to prolonged opening of
questions.explanation:
Presynaptic facilitation is due to prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels . In presynaptic facilitation, the serotonin released at the axoaxonal ending increases the 
intraneuronal cAMP levels phosphorylation and consequent closure of K+ channels  slowing 
of repolarization and prolonging the depolarization by prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels

questions.question:
Question 20: A person with myasthenia gravis notes increased muscle strength when he is treated with an 
acetylcholinesterase (AChE) inhibitor. The basis for his improvement is due to the increase in

options.a: The amount of acetylcholine (ACh) released from motor nerves
options.b: The level of ACh at the muscle end plates
options.c: The number of ACh receptors on the motor end plates
options.d: Synthesis of norepinephrine in motor nerves

questions.explanation:
Treatment with AChE inhibitors (e.g., neostigmine) prevents the degradation of ACh and prolongs 
the action of ACh at the muscle end plate. Myasthenia gravis: • It is caused by the presence of antibodies to the ACh receptor. • Is characterized by skeletal muscle weakness and fatigability resulting from a reduced number of 
ACh receptors on the muscle end plate. • The size of the EPP (end plate potential) is reduced. • Treatment with AChE inhibitors (e.g., neostigmine) prevents the degradation of ACh and 
prolongs the action of ACh at the muscle end plate, partially compensating for the reduced 
number of receptors.

questions.question:
Question 21: A 55-year-old woman had an autonomic neuropathy that disrupted the sympathetic nerve 
supply to the pupillary dilator muscle of her right eye. While having her eyes examined, the 
ophthalmologist placed a sympathomimetic drug in both her eyes. The right eye became 
much more dilated than the left eye. This suggests that:

options.a: The sympathetic nerve to the right eye had regenerated
options.b: The parasympathetic nerve supply to the right eye remained intact and compensated for the
options.d: The left eye also had nerve damage and so was not responding as expected

questions.explanation:
193 
Sold by @itachibot Denervation supersensitivity develops in the muscle after the nerve supplying it is cut. Since the 
nerve to her right dilator pupillae is damaged, the right eye becomes excessively sensitive to the 
sympathomimetic drug. So, the right eye becomes much more dilated than the left. Denervation Supersensitivity: • When the motor nerve to skeletal muscle is degenerated, the muscle gradually becomes 
extremely sensitive to acetylcholine. This is called denervation hypersensitivity or supersensitivity. • Normally nicotinic receptors are located only in the vicinity of the motor endplate where the 
axon of the motor nerve terminates. When the motor nerve is severed, there is a marked 
proliferation of nicotinic receptors over a wide region of the neuromuscular junction. • Denervation supersensitivity also occurs at autonomic junctions. Smooth muscle, unlike skeletal 
muscle, does not atrophy when denervated, but it becomes hyperresponsive to the chemical 
mediator that normally activates it. • This hyperresponsiveness can be demonstrated by using pharmacologic tools rather than actual 
nerve section. Prolonged use of a drug such as reserpine can be used to deplete transmitter stores 
and prevent the target organ from being exposed to norepinephrine for an extended period. Once 
the drug usage is stopped, smooth muscle and cardiac muscle will be supersensitive to subsequent 
release of the neurotransmitter. Option a) If the symapthetic nerve would have regenerated, both right and left eye would have 
been equally sensitive to the drug and so, would have dilated equally. Option b) Parasympathetic nerves supply the spinchter pupillae muscle. So, if stimulated they 
would constrict the eye not dilate it. Also, the drug added was a sympathomimetic agent. So, 
parasympathetic nerves are not stimulated in the first place Option d) If the left eye was damaged, it would also have denervation supersensitivity. Again, both 
eyes would dilate equally, but more than that of normal.

questions.question: Question 22: Which of the following statements is not true about neurotransmitters?

options.a: They must be present at the pre-synaptic membrane
options.b: Neurons must be able to synthesize the substance
options.c: They are released on repolarization of the nerve
options.d: Specific receptors must be present on the post-synaptic membrane

questions.explanation:
Neurotransmitters should be released on depolarization of the terminal. • Neurotransmitters are the substances that mediate chemical signaling between neurons. • The transmission of information at chemical synapses involves the release of neurotransmitter 
from a presynaptic cell, diffusion across the synaptic cleft, and binding of the neurotransmitter to 
specific receptors on the postsynaptic membrane to produce a change in membrane potential. Criteria for the substance to be neurotransmitter • the substance must be demonstrated to be present in the presynaptic terminal • the cell must be able to synthesize the substance. • should be released on depolarization of the terminal. • there should be specific receptors for it on the postsynaptic membrane. • if the substance is applied exogenously to the postsynaptic membrane at physiologic 
concentration, the response of the postsynaptic cell must mimic the in vivo response 194

questions.question:
Question 26: Which of the following electrophysiologic events is correctly paired with the change in ionic 
currents causing the event?

options.a: Fast inhibitory postsynaptic potentials (IPSPs) and closing of Cl– channels
options.b: Fast excitatory postsynaptic potentials (EPSPs) and an decrease in Ca2+ conductance
options.c: Endplate potential and an increase in Na+ conductance
options.d: Presynaptic inhibition and closure of voltage-gated K+ channels

questions.explanation:
Binding of acetylcholine to neuromuscular junction receptors increases the Na+ and K+ 
conductance, and the resultant influx of Na+ produces a depolarizing potential, the endplate 
potential. IPSP may be due to • Opening of chloride ion channels through the postsynaptic neuronal membrane • Increase in conductance of potassium ions out of the neuron. • Activation of receptor enzymes that increase the number of inhibitory synaptic receptors or 
decrease the number of excitatory receptors. EPSP may be due to • The opening of sodium channels to allow large numbers of positive electrical charges to flow to 
the interior of the postsynaptic cell. • Depressed conduction through chloride or potassium channels, or both. • Various changes in the internal metabolism of the postsynaptic neuron to increase the number of 
excitatory membrane receptors or decrease the number of inhibitory membrane receptors.

questions.question:
Question 27: 179 
Sold by @itachibot How is an electrical synapse different from a chemical synapse?
questions.explanation:
In electrical synapses, the cytoplasm of adjacent cells is directly connected by gap junctions 
(connexons) that allow free movement of ions from the interior of one cell to the interior of the 
next cell. The transmission in electrical synapses is bidirectional and there is no synaptic delay. Unlike 
chemical synapses, electrical synapse has cytoplasmic continuity. 196 
Sold by @itachibot Note: Most of the synapses used for signal transmission in the central nervous system are chemical 
synapses. 197
